title: How Bad Are Things?
summary:
Key ideas

- As a psychiatrist, working with people who are miserable and struggling is a daily occurrence, even in wealthy and optimistic American towns.
- Psychiatrists filter for misery and that theoretically makes them more prone to it.
- People automatically have a bias to avoid those who are not like themselves.
- The world has far more pain and suffering than we acknowledge or even imagine.

Key learnings

- Psychiatrists generally treat people who are suffering at the most extreme level of the spectrum.
- The normal way of filtering the people that one meets in life makes it unlikely that one knows people with views that are vastly different from one's own.
- Poll findings show that most people do not understand how many people are genuinely suffering.

Key questions

- Are people biased to filter their social circle based on socioeconomic status?
- Is it possible for individuals to become aware of the extent of pain and suffering in the world and remain mentally healthy?
